Haplochromis burtoni is a species of cichlid fish native to Lake Tanganyika in East Africa. It is a member of the haplochromine group, a diverse group of cichlids found in the Great Lakes of Africa.

Haplochromis burtoni is a small to medium-sized fish, typically reaching lengths of around 10-15 cm. It exhibits pronounced sexual dimorphism, with males being more brightly colored than females. Males typically display vibrant blue, yellow, and orange hues, while females are generally more drab in coloration.

This species is known for its complex social structure and breeding behavior. Haplochromis burtoni lives in hierarchical social groups, with dominant males actively defending territories and actively courting females. The species is considered a maternal mouthbrooder, with females carrying and incubating their fertilized eggs in their mouth until the fry hatch.

Haplochromis burtoni is an important model organism in the study of evolutionary biology, particularly in the context of sexual selection, social behavior, and the mechanisms underlying color polymorphism in cichlid fishes. Its well-studied biology and genetic makeup have contributed to our understanding of the rapid diversification and adaptive radiation of cichlid species in the African Great Lakes.
